Instrument: UPS units. The units switched to battery power for a relatively long - 4 minutes - input power problem.

Instrument: MST Radar. The socket between the radar control PC and beam steering controller was broken unexpectedly. It seems likely that this was connected with the simultaneous input power problem detected by the UPS units. There was a gap of 200 s whilst the radar control PC made repeated efforts to reconnect. The operation of the radar does not appear to have been otherwise affected.

Instrument: UPS units. The units switched to battery power for 11 minutes in response to an input power problem. The unit for TX1 sent a message at 18:44 indicating that the battery power was too low to continue to support the load for much longer. However, it appears to have lasted out until the input power returned to normal a few minutes later. Nevertheless, the MST radar beam steering controller sent a number of alerts during this period.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter powering antenna sector B shut down with error code 7: "analogue parameter error at state 4". DAH restarted it remotely.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of action for this period. It had been giving repeated analogue errors and LD was having difficulties getting it restarted. It was returned to operational status after a new voltage reference component was installed.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector C was out of action during this period owing to a blown fuse. The transmitter for antenna sector B was simultaneously out of action.
Instrument: MST Radar. Beam steering unit 87 gave a brief (i.e. one dwell) indication of low supply voltage before readings returned to normal.
Instrument: MST Radar. The beam steering controller indicated that the transmitters for antenna sectors A, B, and C briefly had low forward power.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter powering antenna sector C was out of action with a blown fuse for much of this period. LD fixed it at 11:35 UT on the following day (2014-04-16) but it proved unstable and was up and down several times over the next few minutes. LD left it in a down state between 11:42 and 14:52 UT. However, it was again up and down several times and LD left it in a down state at 16:22 UT (on 2014-04-16). He then left it for a few days, until 2014-04-23, when he had it up between 14:00 and 14:07 UT. However, it was soon down again with an analogue error (code 7). It was back in action at 09:21 UT on 2014-04-29 but was down again within a minute. It was back up between 11:21 and 13:10 UT and then again at 14:30. It blew its fuse at 22:30 UT the following evening (2014-04-30). It was back up at 08:57 UT on 2014-05-02. This time it lasted 2 days until 08:38 on 2014-05-04. Finally, it has been stable since being restored at 09:13 on 2014-05-06.
Instrument: UPS units. The units switched to battery power twice within a minute, for ~ 1 s each time, in response to an input power power problem.
Instrument: MST Radar. Beam steering unit 37 was indicating high VSWR values, of around 2.5, for much of the day. This led to numerous e-mails being sent by the beam steering controller.
Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was stopped briefly so that LD could change beam steering unit 37, which had been seeing high VSWR values.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Tipping Bucket Raingauge. The raingauge detected only 3 widely-spaced tips (0.2 mm of rain each) during the course of the day, whilst the Vaisala WXT510 sensor detected rain that was more-persistent and more-widespread. It's not clear if this is because the rain really did lead to small accumulations of whether the tipping bucket raingauge is becoming blocked.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Tipping Bucket Raingauge. The instrument failed to detect two rain events - at around 01:30 and 06:30 - 07:30 UT - seen by the WXT510 sensor. LD cleaned out the raingauge at around 09:00 UT and found that it had become blocked.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was stopped so that LD could reinstate the beam steering unit that he had recently removed from quad 37. One of its coils had been loose and he wanted to put it back into service after this was fixed.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Tipping Bucket Raingauge. The raingauge failed to detect rain events measured by the WXT510 on 23rd, 24th, and 25th May 2014. It seems likely that the inlet had not been correctly aligned when LD last cleaned it on 2014-05-13. LD adjusted it on 2014-05-30 and poured a litre of water into it, at around 10:00 UT, in order to establish that it was working. The reading at that time does not represent real rain.
Instrument: UPS units. The UPS units switched to battery power for ~ 1 s in response to an input power problem.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Wind Sensors. There were several instances during this period when the raw data readings, including for wind direction, were all zeros. These do not look realistic. Although at first it was assumed that there had been a malfunction of the data logger, these are possibly artefacts of very low wind speeds, e.g. of the wind speed dropping so low that it cannot overcome the friction of the wind vane's bearings. Although this does not (obviously) explain why the direction readings should also be zero, all cases were associated with low wind speeds. The problem was seen during the follwing, inclusive periods (UT): on 2014-05-26, 20:29 - 20:31, 22:06 - 22:32, 23:27 - 23:33, 23:37 - 23:39, 23:48 - 23:56; on 2014-05-27, 00:00 - 00:12, 01:02 - 01:38, 01:54 - 02:01, 02:10 - 02:29, 02:47 - 03:15, 03:38 - 04:04, 04:12 - 04:31, 19:03 - 19:14, 22:34 - 22:41, 23:11 - 23:59; on 2014-05-28, 00:00 - 00:09, 00:39 - 01:41, 01:55 - 02:00, and 02:12 - 04:24.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar appears to have experience interference during this period. Although the v3 processing was largely successful at avoiding it, some mild contamination of the v4 winds is apparent at altitudes above 14 km.

Instrument: Internet Connection. The internet connection on both the MST and Manchester lines became slow/intermittent during this period. This didn't become apparent until the morning of 2014-07-28, when DAH noticed that file tranfers to RAL were backing up. The time stamps of files at RAL suggest that there were two periods of several hours (during the evenings of 2014-07-24 and 2014-07-26) when no file transfers took place. It appears that the problem was caused by lightning damage at the Capel Bangor exchange. Although Openreach have not yet closed the case, the internet service provider indicated that transfer speeds had been stable since around 2014-08-01 00:00 UT.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter powering antenna sector C was out of action with a blown fuse.
Instrument: MST Radar. The horizontal wind speed from the v4 processing is unrealistically large during this period within a narrow altitude region at around 9.0 km.

Instrument: Surface Met Sensors, Surface Wind Sensors, Vaisala LD40 Laser Ceilometer. PC "Gaius", which logs data from these 3 sets of instruments, encountered an error at around 2014-07-27 14:40 UT. This stopped raw data files from being transferred up to RAL (and prevented DAH from remotely logging on to the PC) although it does not appear to have stopped data from being acquired. DAH was able to access the files once LD had cleared the error message.

Instrument: Vaisala WXT510. The data messages for temperature, pressure, and humidity were showing values of 0.0 for most of this period (realistic-looking data appeared sporadically at the beginning and the end of the period). Although attempts were made to clear the problem, e.g. by power-cycling the unit, these did not have the desired effect. Normal functioning evebtually resumed without any further intervention being taken.

Instrument: Broadband. The "fax" line, which carries the MSTRF's broadband connection, developed a fault. There was no dial tone on the line and a complete loss of broadband. An OpenReach engineer visited the site during the evening of 2014-09-24 having found the source of the problem elsewhere.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was out of action owing to the electricity supply for the whole area being turned off. The latter was to allow essential maintenance work to be carried out by the local supplier. All equipment at the radar site was powered down shortly before the electricity supply was due to be cut and then restarted late in the afternoon.

Instrument: MST Radar. Two of the transmitters, those for antenna sectors B and D were out of action for most of this period and one more, that for sector E, was out of action for part of it. This resulted in reduced altitude coverage. At around 18:35, TXB blew its HV fuse and TXD developed an analogue error (error code 7). TXE blew its HV fuse at 23:51. DAH restarted TXD on several occasions between 07:00 and 08:00, although it was unstable shut down again each time. TXB and TXB were back in action at 08:51 and TXD at 09:34.
Instrument: MST Radar. The radar appears to have suffered from interference, which led to a reduction in altitude coverage.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was powered down durintg this interval to allow LD to switch beam steering unit 94. The latter had intermittently been reporting high VSWR values of between 2.5 and 3.0.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of action fo this period as it would not stay in operation in a stable manner. LD changed the PIN diodes and voltage regulator in the TX/RX power supply before restarting it.

Instrument: MST Radar. The beam steering controller gave a series of unusal error and warning messages indicating a segmentation fault and process failures. This appears to added an extra 40 s to the duration of the 23:11:14 cycle with lengthened gaps betweren the 8th and 9th and between the 11th and 12th dwells. Normal operation appears to have been resumed by the beginning of the following cycle.

Instrument: UPS Units. Three of the six units switched to battery power briefly (~ 1 s) in response to an input power prpblem.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar suffered from a raised noise floor intermittently during this period. It was most prolonged during 2015-01-23 21:30 - 22:50 UT, 2015-01-24 22:10 - 2015-01-25 00:20 UT, 2015-01-25 08:20 - 09:50, 2015-01-25 11:40 - 12:50, 2015-01-25 18:30 - 19:40 UT. This is most evident in the mesospheric observations.

Instrument: UPS Units. The units switched to battery power for approximately 6 s in response to an input power problem. TX4 is known (since 2015-03-19) to have at least 1 faulty battery unit and shut down its output power during this episode. The unit itself is in working order and resumed its output once mains power was restored.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector D (TX4) was out of action during this period. It had shut down when its UPS unit, which was known to have at least one faulty battery, powered down in response to an input power problem. Although the UPS unit quickly restored its output power, the transmitter remained in an idle state until DAH remotely restarted it on the following (Monday) morning.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was powered down twice during this period for approximately 20 minutes on each occasion: 09:05 - 09:24 and 10:37 - 10:56 UT. The first time was to allow LD to change the beam steering unit for location 11. It had become unresponsive a few days earlier, at 2015-03-29 06:48 UT. LD found that one of the components had burnt out. Since he suspected that this was the result of water ingress, he stopped the radar a second time in order to water-proof the connecting cables of the replacement unit.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitters for antenna sectors A and/or B were out of action during this period. This resulted in significantly reduced altitude coverage. DAH was able to restart the transmitter remotely, but it only remained in action for a short period before shutting down again. This happened on many occasions until LD adjusted the measurement circuit in order to ensure a mid-range reading. Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector A was out of action with an analogue error. The error was cleared by the loss of mains/UPS power around 2015-08-23 06 UT, although the transmitter was not properly back in action until 13:45 that afternoon.

Instrument: UPS units. There appears to have been an electricity outage that lasted for over 3 and a half hours. The UPS units became fully discharged after 20 - 30 minutes, leading to all equipment and PCs shutting down. PCs claudius, julius, and tiberius all rebooted automatically when the power was restored. This allowed DAH to remotely restart the MST radar and the WXT520 data acquisition. However, PC gaius was still down at the time of writing.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was out of action during this period owing to a loss of mains electricity, which lasted for over 3 hours. The radar control PC appears to have shut down at around 05:50 UT, after its UPS unit became fully discharged. After the power and internet connection were resumed (shortly after 09 UT), DAH deleted the spectral files for the final, incomplete cycle, which began at 05:47:47 UT. This was in case they crashed the signal processing software. He was able to remotely restart the radar at 12:40 UT, although the beam steering unit does not appear to have been changing the beam pointing direction (DAH had blocked the transfer of data to the Met Office during the restart period). It gave a warning message, "Refusing connection. Beam command socket already connected". Consequently DAH stopped the radar at 13:15 UT before rebooting the beam steering PC, which does not appear to have shut down during the electricity outage. The beam steering unit appeared to operate as expected when DAH restarted the radar at 13:45 UT. However, he did not remove the block from the Met Office's data feed until around 15:30 UT, when he was confident that everything was back to normal.

Instrument: MST Radar, UPS Units, Vaisala LD40, Vaisala WXT520, Sky Camera 2. A prolonged loss of power at the radar site led to all data aquisition computers shutting down. An engineer from the local electricity distribution company (Scottish Power) visited the site around the middle of the day and established that the source of the problem was internal and not with the supply. It turned out to be a failure within the local distribution circuits. A local electrician carried out repairs during the afternoon.

Instrument: MST Radar. The MST radar did not produce any useful data during most of this period. An input power problem at 2015-11-06 20:40 led to the UPS unit for the transmitter powering antenna sector C to shut down. This unit is known (from self-tests) to have a faulty battery pack. The delivery of a replacement pack has been delayed by supplier problems. This UPS unit also powers the phase synchronistaion unit, which must be in operation in order for the transmitters to be able to transmit. However, the receiver continued to acquire (noise) data. DAH spotted this on the following morning and stopped the radar at 08:20 in an attempt to diagnose the problem. He restarted the radar at 10:06 but stopped it again at 10:58, when it became clear that the problem could not be resolved remotely. LD visited the site on the morning of 2015-11-09 and swapped the recently replaced battery pack from the UPS for TXA to the UPS for TXC. Four of the transmitters were back in action at 09:41 and the transmitter for antenna sector A was back in action at 10:19.

Instrument: UPS units. The units switched to battery power in response to a 2 s input power problem. The unit powering the transmitter for antenna sector C, which was known to have a faulty battery, failed to restart after the problem. Since it is also responsible for powering the phase synchronisation unit, none of the transmitters could operate until the power to this unit was restored.

Instrument: UPS units. The units briefly (~ 1 s) switched to battery, in response to input power problems, on 5 occasions during this 3 minute period. The unit for the beam steering unit encountered battery problems during these events, which led to its output power being briefly disconnected. This led to the beam steering PC tiberius going through a reboot. DAH had stopped and restarted the MST radar briefly before this. However, since no useful data were being collected, owing to the phase synchronisation unit already being out of action, the consequences were insignificant.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of actopn during this period owing to a blown fuse.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector A was out of action during this period to allow maintenance work to be carried out.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of action during this period owing to a blown fuse.
Instrument: UPS units. The units for TXB, TXD, TXE, and for the beam steering unit performed self tests during this period. The unit for the beam steering unit reported a faulty battery.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of action during this period owing to a blown fuse. The transmitter for antenna sector B was briefly out of action at the very end of this period (08:51 - 08:57) woing to LD having switched it off by mistake.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector D was out of action on a number of occasions owing to an analogue error. DAH was able to remotely restart the transmitter, which meant that it was in operation during the following periods on 2015-11-16: 09:40 - 09:42, 10:08 - 10:08, 11:40 - 11:53 UT.
Instrument: MST Radar. There appears to have been a short break in the connection between the radar control and beam steering PCs.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector A was out of action for maintenance.

Instrument: MST Radar. During this period the transmitter for antenna section D briefly reported low output power and beam steering unit 47 (which is in antenna section D) briefly reported an elevated value of VSWR.

Instrument: MST Radar. During this period the transmitter for antenna section D briefly reported low output power and beam steering units 47, 58, 64, 65, 66, and 67 (all in antenna section D) briefly reported elevated values of VSWR.

Instrument: MST Radar. During this period the transmitter for antenna section D briefly reported low output power and beam steering units 47, 48, 57, 64, 65, 66 (all in antenna section D) briefly reported an elevated value of VSWR.

Instrument: MST Radar. During this period the transmitter for antenna section D briefly reported low output power and beam steering unit 47 (also antenna section D) briefly reported an elevated value of VSWR.

Instrument: UPS units. Four of the UPS units passed a self-test: TX2 at 14:03, TX4 at 14:05, Beamform at 14:05, and TX5 at 15:25.

Instrument: UPS units. Two of the UPS units passed a self-test: TX3 at 09:26, and TX1 at 10:11.

Instrument: UPS unit TX2. This unit failed a self test at the beginning of the priod. LD installed a replacement battery pack at the end of the period. In the mean time, the UPS unit sent 18,592 e-mail messages complianing about the state of its batteries.
Instrument: UPS units. Three of the UPS units passed a self-test: TX4 at 14:04, Beamform at 14:04, and TX5 at 15:24. TX2 failed the self test at 14:02.
Instrument: MST Radar. Beam steering unit 95 updated its software.
Instrument: UPS units. Two of the UPS units passed a self-test: TX3 at 09:26, and TX1 at 10:11.

Instrument: UPS units. Four of the units (TX1, TX3, TX4, and TX5) switched to battery power in response to a brief (~ 1 s) input power problem. However, two of the units (TX2, and Beamform) reported that the output power was turned off due to a low battery. This was unexpected since both units passed self tests a few hours later. This led to a short disruption in the observation schedule.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter was antenna sector B went into a passive state after its UPS failed to power it during a brief input power problem.

Instrument: MST Radar. The time taken to complete the 6th dwell on the cycle starting at 04:02:17 was extended from 26 s to 122 s. This was the result of the beam steering PC (tiberius) being forced to reboot after its UPS (Beamform) failed to power it during a brief input power problem.
Instrument: UPS units. The units for TX2, TX4, TX5, and Beamform passed self tests during this period.

Instrument: UPS units. Four of the UPS units passed a self-test: TX2 at 14:01, TX4 at 14:03, Beamform at 14:04, and TX5 at 15:24.
Instrument: MST Radar. The beam steering controller indicated that the output from the transmitter powering antenna sector B was slightly below normal for a single dwell.

Instrument: UPS units. The units switched to battery power in response to a brief (~ 1 s) input power problem. The units for TX2 and Beamform appear to have behaved as expected on this occasion, despite not having switched to battery power during recent input power problems.
Instrument: MST Radar. The beam steering unit indicated that the output power of the transmitter for antenna sector B was slightly below expected for a single dwell.
Instrument: UPS units. Two of the units passed self tests during this period - TX3 at 09:25 and TX1 at 10:08
Instrument: UPS units. Five of the units (TX1, TX2, TX3, TX4, and Beamform) switched to battery power in response to a brief (~ 1 s) input power problem.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of action with a blown fuse.
Instrument: MST Radar. The output power from the transmitter for antenna sector D was slightly below expected 3 times during this period.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit for TX5 failed a self test during this period owing to a faulty battery.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of action with a blown fuse.

Instrument: UPS units. Three of the units passed a self test - TX2 at 14:00, TX4 at 14:02, and Beamform at 14:03. TX5 initially reported a faulty battery, but passed the self test at 15:22.

Instrument: MST Radar, WXT520, Sky Camera 2, LD40. All equipment at the radar site had to be powered down in order to allow the local electricity distribution company to carry out sheduled work. This issue affected the whole Capel Dewi area.

Instrument: UPS Units. The units briefly (~ 1 s) switched to battery power in response to an input power problem. It's not clear whether this was an actual problem or related to the fact that the transmitters were being switched back into operation at this time.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector C blew its fuse almost immediately after the radar was restarted (following a scheduled power outage). LD had in back in operation 20 minutes later.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of action with a blown fuse.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector C was out of action with a blown fuse. This led to a noticeable reduction in radar return signal power and in useful altitude coverage.

Instrument: UPS units. The units switched to battery power in response to a ~ 2 s input power problem. The unit TX5, which was known to have a faulty battery, does not appear to have recovered from this problem and the the associated transmitter, for antenna sector E, shut down.

Instrument: MST Radar, UPS Units. The transmitter for antenna sector E was out of action during this period owing to the failure of its UPS unit. The transmitter could not be powered through an adjacent UPS unit since the combined load of two transmitters was too large for one unit. Moreover, it couldn't be powered directly from the mains supply since the latter is reduced to 220 V by a "voltage optimisation unit". The transmitters require a input voltage of 240 V. The transmitter restarted operations after a replacement UPS unit was installed on 2016-03-08 11:24 UT. The transmitter was briefly in operation 11:05 - 11:20 UT and again for less than a minute at 11:52 UT before stable operations were resumed at 12:21 UT.

Instrument: MST Radar. During this period, the status of beam steering units 81, 82, 91, and 92 alternated between being responsive and unresponsive on several occasions. All of these units are feb by the same power divider and belong to antenna sector E. The corresponding transmitter was out of action at this time owing to its UPS unit failing during the previous night.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was stopped during this period to allow LD to inspect the power splitter that feeds quads 81, 82, 91, and 92, which had all been unresponsive. LD found that the connector was in a degraded state and so terminated the output with a dummy load.

Instrument: MST Radar. The beam steering controller indicated that units 81, 82, and 91 alternated between being unresponsive and then responsive again during this period. Shortly afterwards (by 16:00) LD replaced the N-type connector on the input to the power splitter that feeds these units. The original connector had not been sealed properly and so had become corroded. LD suspected that the power splitter for units 41, 42, 51, and 52 might be suffering from a similar problem since he is getting unusual controller readings from this part of the atenna array. However, he did not inspect the relevant connectors on this occasion.
Instrument: UPS Units. The units TX1 and TX3 passed their self tests during this period.
Instrument: UPS Units. Units TX2, TX4, and Beamform passed self tests during this period.

Instrument: MST Radar. The beam steering controller sent a large number (nearly 200) of notifications during this period alternately noting that the supply voltage for unit 30 was too low (at around 0.3 V) and then that it was normal (23.2 V). LD replaced the unit whilst the radar was down 2016-03-03 09:58 - 11:24 UT for other reasons.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was powered down whilst Aberystwyth University students carried out a surveying exercise on the antenna array. LD took the opportunity to replace beam steering unit 30, which had been giving error messages.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector A was out of action during this period owing to an analogue error. DAH was able remotely to clear the error and to put the transmitter back into operation.
Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector B was out of action with a blown fuse.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for antenna sector C was out of action owing to a blown fuse. This led to a significant reduction in useful altitude coverage. The transmitter was briefly back in operation 3 times on 2016-03-15 before it became stable: 11:03 - 11:04, 11:18 - 11:20, and 11:33 - 11:35 UT.

Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 gave the following messages in short succession: "Critical - System: Warmstart", "Informational - UPS: Restored the local network management interface-to-UPS communication.", and "Informational - UPS: The output power is now turned on." These appear to indicate that the network management card was unable to detect another device on the network and so restarted as a failsafe measure.

Instrument: MST Radar, LD40, Sky-Camera 2, WXT520. The electricity supply to the whole Capel Dewi area was down to allow the distribution company to carry out scheduled maintenance work. Consequently all equipment at the MST Radar site was powered down for the day. Data from the WXT520 started to be collected again at 16:28 UT, but there was a gap 16:51 - 17:21 UT owing to acquisition PC julius having to be rebooted. There were no gaps in the data collected from the Campbell Scientific surface met and surface wind sensors.

Instrument: Broadband Connection. The internet connection was lost, apparently as a result of thuderstorms in the vicinity of the MST radar site. LD was away over this Bank Holiday weekend and so no action could be taken until the Tuesday morning when DPW was on site. It's not clear whether the loss of connection was the result of a failed broadband filter or router. However, the connection was eventually reestablised after both were changed.

Instrument: (Frongoch) Surface Wind Sensors. No surface wind data are available for this period. The Campbell Scientific data logger can hold just over two-and-a-half-days' worth of data before overwriting itself. Consequenly data were lost by the 3 day phone/internet outage, which prevented any downloads from being made.

Instrument: Broadband, MST Radar, Frongoch Wind Sensors. The internet/phone connections to the site were lost, apparently as a result of a violent storm that affected the Aberystwyth area. Trees were uprooted and caravans were overturned. MST radar and surface wind data for the period were affected.

Instrument: MST Radar. The st300 Cartesian data for 2016-11-18 - 2016-11-20, inclusive, have not been made available to the data archive. They have large time-altitude regions of missing winds owing to a known issue the time-continuity quality-control algorithm when the external internet connection is down for more than 24 hours. The intermediate files are not cleared from the processing chain, which leads to wind data being compared with observations made at around the same time on previous days. When the wind field is variable, this leads to gaps in the data although the quality of available data should not be significantly affected. The missing files can be made available upon request.

Instrument: MST Radar. The beam steering PC (tiberius) failed to respond between 22:16:27 and 22:21:19 UTC. This appears to be in some way connected with an input power problem experience by the UPS units between 22:04 and 22:21 UTC. However, the beam steering control PC (tiberius) appears to have remained in operation during this period. The problem caused a delay of 291 s between the 3rd and 4th dwells of the observation cycle that began at 22:15:09 UTC.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific. Although the tipping bucket rangauge detected rain throughout much of 2017-06-05, the last measurement was made at 21:40 UTC. The WXT520 measurements suggest that 6.9 mm more rain fell between then and 24:00 UTC. LD cleaned out the raingauge a few days later and found a build up of algae, a slug on the tipping mechanism, and an ants' nest.

Instrument: MST Radar. The transmitter for anetnna sector C was out of action owing to an analgue error. Instrument: Campbell Sci Surface Met sensors. LD poured water into the tipping bucket raingauge on two occasions in order to check whether or not it was functioning correctly. The precipitation data have therefore been blanked for the periods 09:00 - 09:20 and 10:40 - 11:00 UTC. In recent days the sensor had failed to to register rain detected by the Vaisala WXT520 on several occasions, even after LD had cleaned a blockage of the filter gauze on the morning of 2017-09-22.

Instrument: UPS Units. The units switched to battery power for approximately 5 s each on 10 occasions during this period - 00:05:01, 00:05:47, 00:07:09, 00:08:10, 00:09:11, 00:10:01, 00:11:22, 00:16:16, 00:17:38, and 02:44:35 UTC - in response to input power problems. A final switch to battery power at 02:45:12 UTC must have lasted for at least 20 minutes, since the UPS units became discharged. This caused operations of the MST Radar, the LD40 ceilometer, and the WXT520 weather sensors to cease.

Instrument: MST Radar. Radar operations stopped as a result of a power outage at 02:45 UTC, which caused the UPS units to become discharged. LD restarted the radar at 10:33 UTC. However, owing to a connection issue to the beam steering PC (tiberius), the beam remained in a vertically pointing direction. Consequently the horizontal wind data are invalid until 16:53 UTC when tiberius was rebooted.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Wind Sensors. Wind direction readings are unavailable during this period. It was not clear whether the wind vane or the connecting cable (which is over 15 years old) was the cause of the problem, so both were replaced (as was the cable for the anemometer). The delay in installing the replacement sensor and cables was caused by a mixture of weather conditions and LD being able to find someone who was able to help him winch down the measurement tower.

Instrument: MST Radar. The data processing PC (claudius) developed a hard disk fault, which prevented it from processing MST radar data in a timely way. At first, the fact that the latest data quick look plots were not being updated was attributed to an internet problem. However, LD discovered the fault during a visit to the site on the afternoon of 2018-04-01 and he rebooted the PC. Although this restored some functionality - the latest MST radar data plots were being updated, but showed no data - the performance of the PC was very poor even for command line functions such listing directory contents. The performance of the PC appears to have improved by itself without any additional intervention having been taken. PC claudius is quite old and is due to be replaced within the next week.

Instrument: MST Radar. The v3 Cartesian files for this period have not been made available since they contain large gaps in useful coverage. This is a result of a known software issue that prevents data from being cleared from the processing flow when the internet connection is lost. This in turn leads to the time-continuity quality control algorithm from being applied incorrectly.

Instrument: Internet. The internet connection to the site was lost during this period. At first this was attributed to Openreach carrying out a "regrade" on the Capel Bangor telephone exchange. However, the problem persisted after the work was completed. LD switched the MSTRF's router to the University of Manchester line on 2018-05-11, which allowed some of the backlog of files to be transferred. An Openreach engineer visited the site on the afternoon of 2018-05-12 and confirmed that the source of the problem had been at the exchange.

Instrument: UPS Units, MST Radar, Vaisala LD40, Vaisala WXT520, Sky-Camera-2. A loss of electricity beginning at 04:37 appears to have led to the UPS units becoming discharged and in all equipment shutting down. DAH had to reboot the radar control and beam steering PCs (julius and tiberius) before he could get the radar to restart at 08:13. He restarted the WXT520 at 10:54. LD had to manually restart PC gaius, when he reached site, before he the LD40 acquisition began.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific met sensors. Data from the tipping bucket raingauge suggest a reasonable quantity of rain during this period, despite the facts that the Vaisala WXT520 detected nothing and that there was no indication of rain in the MST radar observations (the cloud base detected by the Vaisala LD40 was too low to be certain whether or not there was rain). Nevertheless, images from the Sky-Camera-2 suggest that the rain was real.

Instrument: Broadband. The broadband connection to the radar site was slow to the point of being unusable during this period. The internet service provider could see no problems on the line, but carried out a reset at the local exchange for good measure. This did not clear the problem. LD made a special visit to the site and first tried changing the filter (which had no effect) before power-cycling the router (which did).

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was stopped during this period to allow LD to swap beam steering unit 90, which had been intermittently reporting a low supply voltage since 2018-09-24 12:31 UTC. There is a short gap between the 1st and 2nd radar observation cycles after the radar was restarted at 10:42 since DAH had not restarted the software in the "nohup" mode on the first occasion.

The MST Radar v3 Cartesian file for this day has not been released owing to signs of unrealistically strong winds between 10:10 and 11:20 UTC and within a narrow altitude band around 16 km. These are significantly faster than at adjacent times and altitudes and are thought to be a consequence of strong mountain wave activity.

Instrument: UPS Units, MST Radar, Vaisala LD40, Vaisala WXT520, Sky-Camera-2. The electricity supply for the whole Capel Dewi area was down during this period to allow the distribution company to carry out maintenance on their equipment. This meant that all MSTRF instruments/computers were powered down between 08:50 and 09:00 UTC. The electricity supply was restored at 16:15 UTC. The MST radar was restarted at 18:04 UTC and the WXT520 data acquisition at 18:24. At the time of writing, the LD40 data acquisition has not been restarted owing to an apparent problem with its acquisition computer "gaius".

Instrument: UPS units, MST Radar, Vaisala WXT520, Vaisala LD40, Sky-Camera-2, Campell Sci. surface met sensors, Cambell Sci surface wind sensors. There appears to have been a power outage at the radar site between approximately 16:42 and 18:07 UTC - possibly as the result of strong surface winds. DAH spotted this shortly after the power was restored and was able to remotely restart the MST radar at 19:52 UTC. The Vaisala WXT520 data acquisition was restarted at 18:54 UTC. The Sky-Camera-2 acquisition restarted automatically when PC julius restarted. PC gaius failed to restart automatically and so, at the time of writing, Vaisala LD40 acquisition has not restarted. Data from the Campbell Scientific surface met and wind sensors can only be downloaded when PC gaius is back in operation and so it is not yet known if the data acquisition was affected.

Instrument: Tipping bucket rain gauge. Only 1 tip (i.e. an accumulation of 0.2 mm) was recorded during this period (10:20 - 10:30 UTC), despite the fact that the WXT520 recorded 1.06 mm. Owing to the cold surface temperatures at thus time (approximately 3 degrees C), it is likely the the precipitation was not entirely liquid.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: Tipping bucket rain gauge. Three tips were recorded during this period - 12:10 - 12:20, 15:50 - 16:00, and 18:00 - 18:10 UTC. However, backscatter data from the LD40 suggests that only the last of these was associated with precipitation. Owing to the near 0 degrees C temperatures at this time, the other two tips might be have been caused by melting of snow or frost.

Instrument: MST Radar. The wind speed within a few narrow time-altitude regions above 17.5 km is significantly faster than at adjacent times and altitudes. This suggests that the values are not realistic. Three notable regions are between approximately 13:10 and 13:50 UTC and at an altitude of around 18.0 km, between approximately 17:45 and 18:15 UTC and at an altitude of around 19.0 km, and between approximately 23:30 and 23:59 UTC and at an altitude of around 18.0 km. This issue affects both v3 and v4 data.

Data between 01:00 and 03:00 UTC should be ignored. A bug in the netCDF file creation software causes times between 01:00 and 02:00 UTC to be interpreted as occurring one hour later on the day when civil time changes between Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) and British Summer Time (BST). The source of the problem has been identified and tests have shown that it interprets times prior to 01:00 UTC and those after 02:00 UTC correctly. However, since it is impossible to distinguish between cycles that actually occurred between 02:00 and 03:00 and those that occurred between 01:00 and 02:00 UTC, data for this period should be ignored.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced an elevated noise level, which resulted in the useful altitude coverage being limited to just a few km. LD switched off the output power from the transmitters (at around 2019-09-04 12:00) in an attempt to isolate the problem. The transmitters are still inactive at the time of writing this entry (2019-09-05 08:00).

Instrument: MST Radar. LD switched off the output power of the transmitters during this period in an attempt to track down/remove the cause of the raised receiver noise floor (it is clear from the signal power that this did not have the desired effect). LD attached a dummy load to the receiver input at 2019-09-05 14:08 UTC in order to test if the noise problem was caused by the receiver itself. However, this caused the data processing software to crash (probably because of the lack of structure in the Doppler spectra). DAH did not notice this until the following morning (at around 2019-09-06 10:00 UTC), when LD confirmed that the transmitters had been back in operation since approximately 2019-09-05 16:00 UTC. DAH removed the spectral files for the period 2019-09-05 14:08 - 17:01 UTC, which allowed the data processing software to continue automatically.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The receiver experienced a raised noise floor during this period. It was particularly noticeable between 13:00 and 13:40 UTC. This event led to slightly reduced altitude coverage for wind-profiling purposes, although the quality of the data should not have been affected.
Instrument: UPS Units. Unit TX3 passed a self test at this time.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The receiver experienced a (time-varying) raised noise floor during this period, which led to slightly reduced altitude coverage. However, this should not have affected the quality of the data that were flagged as being reliable.

Instrument: UPS Units. Units TX2, TX4, and Beamform passed self tests during this period.

Instrument: MST Radar. The receiver experienced a raised noise floor during this period, which led to a reduction in useful altitude coverage. The radar was stopped briefly between 2019-09-10 08:52 and 09:00 UTC to allow LD to replace the receiver with the backup unit. It's not clear whether this action was responsible for the reduction in noise level around this time.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The measured wind directions during this period are incorrect (by 180 degrees). This was caused by the I and Q channels having been inadvertently switched when the spare receiver was swapped for the main one (despite the connections being made according to the labelling) in an attempt to eliminate the recent problem of a raised noise floor. As it happens, the problem with the raised noise floor persisted with the new receiver.

Instrument MST Radar. The altitude coverage was noticeably reduced during this period. This was initially thought to have been caused by more than one transmitter being out of action. However, it turns out to have been the result of the output voltage of a new UPS unit for TXE being set to 220 V rather than the 240 V preferred by the transmitters. It's not entirely clear why the altitude coverage was lower when TXE was in operation at the lower voltage than when it was out of operation.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific wind sensors. No data were collected during this period owing the failure of the power supply for the data logger. Although the wind speeds measured since 2019-11-29 look reliable, the wind directions are typically confined to the range 45 degrees +/1 10 degrees, which is clearly incorrect. The cause of the problem is not yet known at the time of adding this entry (2020-02-19).
Instrument: UPS Units. Unit TX3 passed a self test at this time.
Instrument: MST Radar. The altitude coverage became severely restricted during this period as a result of a raised receiver noise floor.

Instrument: MST Radar. The useful altitude coverage was restricted between 00:00 and approximately 10:30 UTC as a result of a raised receiver noise floor. Thereafter the transmitters were set into a non-transmitting mode to allow tests to be carried out. Normal operations were resumed at 14:00 UTC, but without TXA in operation. It is not clear whether the transmitter or its corresponding antenna sector was the source of the problem.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a raised noise floor and a reduction in useful altitude coverage between 00:00 and 13:30 UTC, when LD disconnected the receiver feed for antenna sector A. Further instances of a raised noise floor were experienced 14:30 - 15:50, and 19:00 - 20:00 UTC, although their effects were less pronounced.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was stopped to allow LD to investigate the power supply for the beam steering units. However, he spent all of this time trying to determine the cause of the raised noise floor experienced by the receiver. The receiver feed for antenna sector A was disconnected at around 13:30 UTC.
Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a slightly raised noise floor between 04:00 and 05:30, which led to a mild reduction in useful altitude coverage.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.
Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a few short episodes of a mildly raised noise floor between 12:00 and 23:59. This had a negligible effect on useful altitude coverage.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a raised noise floor and a reduction in useful altitude coverage between 03:00 and 08:55 UTC, when the radar was stopped in preparation for a power-down of the whole site. The receiver feed for antenna sector A was disconnected when the radar was restarted at 16:30 UTC. It had only been reconnected at 10:15 UTC on the previous day (2019-11-19).

Instrument: MST Radar, Vaisala LD40, Vaisala WXT520, Sky-Camera-2. The electricity supply to the whole of the Capel Dewi valley was cut during this period in order to allow the local distribution company to carry out scheduled maintenance on their infrastructure. The data acquisition computers were shut down between 08:45 and 09:00 UTC. The MST Radar was restarted at 16:30 UTC. Data acquisition for the other instruments was restarted at around 15:00 UTC.
Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a few episodes of a slightly raised noise floor between 14:30 and 17:30, which led to mild reductions in useful altitude coverage.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a few brief episodes of a slightly raised noise floor between 11:15 and 20:45 UTC. These did not appear to have any effect on the useful altitude coverage.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a few episodes of a raised noise floor, principally between 02:30 and 06:00 UTC, when the useful altitude coverage was noticeably reduced.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced multiple short episodes of a raised noise floor between 02:00 and 16:00 UTC. This had a mild effect on the useful altitude coverage for vertical beam observations but a less noticeable one for the horizontal winds.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a few episodes of a raised noise floor between 00:00 and 19:00 UTC. The one occurring between 03:00 and 05:15 led a noticeable reduction in useful altitude coverage.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific surface met sensors. The timing of rain events seen by the tipping bucket rain gauge during this period were often inconsistent with those apparent from the Vaisala LD40 laser ceilometer backscatter plots. In particular, the tipping bucket rain gauge showed rain continuing after the LD40 indicated that a rain event had ceased. This suggested a blockage in the tipping bucket. LD cleaned the inlet filter shortly before 2019-12-13 10:30 UTC. He reported that it had been covered in slime. The first time that a mismatch was potentially apparent was 2019-11-28 23:00, although it was not until the middle of the day on 2019-12-06 that it became obvious.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: Campbell Sci. tipping bucket rain gauge. The timing of rain events detected by the tipping bucket rain gauge during this period do not match those derived from the Vaisala LD40 laser ceilometer backscatter signals. In particular, there are many instances when the tipping bucket rain gauge suggests that rain is continuing to fall long after the LD40 indicates that it has stopped. This was caused by a build up of slime on the inlet filter to the rain gauge.

Instrument: MST Radar. There are a few narrow time-altitude regions - notably around 15.5 km and between 10:00 and 10:45 UTC, and around 14 km and between 04:30 and 05:10 UTC - within which the wind speed is significantly faster than at adjacent times and altitudes. This effect is more pronounced in the v4.0 than in the v3.2 data files. It is not clear whether or not these speeds are realistic (being the result of mountain wave activity).

This suggests that the values might not be realistic. The effect is more pronounced in the v4.0 than in the v3.2 data files.

Instrument: Surface wind sensors at Frongoch. No data were transferred during this period after the 3G modem went offline. LD had to power-cycle it in order to restart the feed. The end time of the restart is estimated. It was at some point around the middle of the day on 2020-01-24.

Instrument: MST Radar. There is a sudden drop in useful altitude coverage at 01:00 UTC, which coincides with a failure of the broadband router. These problems are thought to have been caused by a thunderstorm in the locality. However, it is not yet clear why the radar altitude coverage was reduced.

Instrument: MST Radar. The receiver experienced a slightly raised noise floor between 18:00 and 23:59 UTC, which led to a slight reduction in useful altitude coverage.
Instrument: MST Radar. The receiver experienced a slightly raised noise floor, primarily between 00:00 and 10:30 UTC, which led to a slight reduction in useful altitude coverage.

Instrument: MST Radar. A loss of mains power at 16:15 UTC led to the radar shutting down. Although it was restarted at 19:15 UTC, the beam steering unit was stuck in a single off-vertical direction. The corresponding wind profile data are consequently invalid.

Instrument: MST Radar. The beam steering unit was was stuck in a single off-vertical direction between 00:00 and 08:50 UTC after a loss of mains power the previous evening. The wind profile data are invalid during this period. The radar was restarted after the beam steering computer was rebooted.
Instrument: MST Radar. The radar was powered down during this period in order to allow electrical work to be carried out in the transmitter room.
Instrument: UPS Units. Units TX2, TX3, TX4, TX5, and Beamform passed self tests during this period.

Instrument: MST Radar. The altitude coverage is noticeably reduced between 06:45 and 23:59 UTC. This is the result of a bug in the time-continuity quality control algorithm, which is only triggered when the internet connection is unavailable for more than 24 hours. The break in internet connection originally occurred during the evening of 2020-03-07.

Instrument: MST Radar. The altitude coverage is reduced throughout the day, most noticeably between 06:45 and 23:59 UTC. This is the result of a bug in the time-continuity quality control algorithm, which is only triggered when the internet connection is unavailable for more than 24 hours. The break in internet connection originally occurred during the evening of 2020-03-07.

Instrument: MST Radar. The altitude coverage is reduced throughout the day, most noticeably between 18:30 and 23:59 UTC. This is the result of a bug in the time-continuity quality control algorithm, which is only triggered when the internet connection is unavailable for more than 24 hours. The break in internet connection originally occurred during the evening of 2020-03-07.

Instrument: MST Radar. The altitude coverage is reduced throughout the day. This is the result of a bug in the time-continuity quality control algorithm, which is only triggered when the internet connection is unavailable for more than 24 hours. The break in internet connection originally occurred during the evening of 2020-03-07.

Instrument: MST Radar. The altitude coverage is reduced throughout the day, most noticeably prior to 12:00 UTC. This is the result of a bug in the time-continuity quality control algorithm, which is only triggered when the internet connection is unavailable for more than 24 hours. The break in internet connection originally occurred during the evening of 2020-03-07.

Instrument: MST Radar. The altitude coverage is reduced between 00:00 and 11:15 UTC. This is the result of a bug in the time-continuity quality control algorithm, which is only triggered when the internet connection is unavailable for more than 24 hours. The break in internet connection originally occurred during the evening of 2020-03-07.

Instrument: MST Radar. The useful altitude coverage is slightly reduced between 15:00 and 23:59 UTC as a result of an occasionally raised noise floor. The latter is thought to have been caused by a connection to the receiver feed of equipment that was intended to monitor for a the cause of the raised noise floor.

Instrument: MST Radar. The useful altitude coverage is slightly reduced between 00:00 and 12:50 UTC as a result of an occasionally raised noise floor. The latter is thought to have been caused by a connection to the receiver feed of equipment that was intended to monitor for a the cause of the raised noise floor. This equipment was removed at 12:50 UTC.
Instrument: UPS Units. Units TX2, TX3, TX4, TX5, and Beamform passed self tests during this period.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The data between 01:00 and 03:00 UTC should be ignored. Owing to an understood bug in the processing software, the time stamps are misinterpreted during the change from GMT to BST. This affects all MST Radar data products except the spectral data.

Instrument: MST Radar. There are a few instances, at altitudes above 15 km, of wind speeds that are significantly faster than at adjacent times and altitudes and so might not be realistic. The most obvious of these is between 02:20 and 03:00 UTC at an altitude of around 18 km. It is less clear if the one between 13:00 and 13:40 UTC at an altitude of around 17.5 km is realistic or not.
Instrument: UPS Units. Units TX2, TX3, TX4, TX5, and Beamform passed self tests during this period.

Instrument: MST Radar. The horizontal wind speed between 12:10 and 15:00 UTC is unrealistically low and should not be used. This suggests a problem with the beam steering (although the wind directions are consistent with those seen immediately before and after the period). It is likely to have been caused by work on 3 of the transmitters, which had been out of action. Two of these transmitters were brought back into to operation by having their fuses changed, but the third could not be.
Instrument: UPS Units. Units TX2, TX3, TX4, TX5, and Beamform passed self tests during this period.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The are numerous periods during the day when the noise floor was raised slightly. This can be seen in the signal power but does not have an effect on the coverage or the quality of the wind data.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The receiver noise floor was raised during a brief period just after 10:00 UTC. This can be seen in the signal power but does not have an effect on the coverage or the quality of the wind data.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. There was a brief problem with the radar between approximately 10:30 and 11:10 UTC. This resulted in a raised noise floor and some clearly unrealistic vertical velocity values at around 11:00 UTC. The horizontal wind data do not appear to have been significantly affected.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met Sensors. The tipping bucket raingauge recorded a single tip during this period despite the fact that the LD40 shows clear skies. It is possible that this was caused by overnight condensation on the bucket although the fact that this occurred several hours after sunrise, when the temperature had risen significantly, cast doubt on this possibility.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The noise floor was slightly raised between approximately 09:30 and 09:30 UTC. This appears to have given rise to some vertical vertical velocity values at altitudes above 12 km that are slightly different to those at adjacent times. However, the horizontal wind data do not appear to be significantly affected.

Instrument: MST Radar. Some of the vertical velocities at altitudes above 12 km and at times between approximately 11:15 and 11:30 UTC are noticeably different to those at adjacent times. These do not appear to be realistic. The horizontal wind data do not appear to be significantly affected.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instruments: MST Radar, Vaisala LD40, Vaisala WXT520. For reasons that are not clear, the output of the Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) unit for the receiver room appears to have cut out at around 07:45 UTC (none of the UPS units in the transmitter room reported any input power problems). The computers in the receiver room appear to have automatically restarted almost immediately. DAH was able to restart the MST Radar and the WXT520 data acquisition remotely, but had to wait for LD to visit the site in order to restart the LD40 data acquisition.

Instrument: MST Radar. The horizontal wind speeds between 09:25 and 11:30 UTC at altitudes above 9 km are noticeably different to those at adjacent times. These do not appear to be realistic and are assumed to to be caused by some sort of signal contamination. The gap in observations between 07:45 and 09:25 UTC was caused by a loss of power to the data acquisition computer.
Instrument: UPS units. The unit TX5 carried out a system warmstart.

Instrument: MST Radar. The noise floor was slightly raised between approximately 15:00 and 15:30 UTC. This appears to have given rise to some vertical vertical velocity values at altitudes above 12 km that are slightly different to those at adjacent times. However, the horizontal wind data do not appear to be significantly affected.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar experienced a raised noise floor between 13:45 and 14:15 UTC, which is more apparent in the m-mode data than the st-mode data. The wind data are already flagged as being unreliable, which might be the result of the rapid vertical velocity variations caused by the convection.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met. The first tip registered by the tipping bucket rain gauge at 12:10 UTC was possibly caused by melting snow or frost. ice or dew. The temperature had dropped to -4 degrees C during the preceding hours. The Vaisala LD40 suggests some precipitation before 12:00 UTC, but not at the time of the tip. The subsequent tips registered by the tipping bucket rain gauge correspond in time to indications of precipitation from the Vaisala LD40.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met. The tipping bucket rain gauge recorded no accumulation during this period, when the temperature only rose marginally above 0 degrees C. The Vasiala LD40 suggests that there was intermittent precipitation during this period. It's not clear whether the accumulation was too little to cause a tip or whether it fell as snow.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met Instruments. The water measured by the tipping bucket rain gauge between 14:20 and 15:50 UTC is likely to be the result of melting snow/ice. Instrument: MST Radar. All data between 01:00 and 06:45 UTC should be ignored. DAH had made a small change to the processing code to deal with a known bug that is encountered during the period 01:00 - 03:00 UTC on the day when the clocks change from GMT to BST. The change did not have the desired effect and DAH removed it at around 2021-03-28 08:00 UTC.

Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met. The tip registered by the tipping bucket rain gauge at 05:00 UTC was probably caused by an accumulation of dew since the Vaisala LD40 shows clear skies at this time.

Instrument: MST Radar. Data products are not currently available for the period 00:00 - 16:30 UTC. This is the result of a failure of the data processing PC at around 2021-09-17 16:30 UTC. Nevertheless, the raw data were collected for this period.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar receiver experienced a raised noise floor during the interval 04:50 - 07:00 UTC. Although this did not lead to contamination of the data products, it did result in a reduction in useful altitude coverage.
Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met. The single tip registered by the tipping bucket rain gauge between 10:40 and 10:50 UTC was probably the result of melting frost.

Instrument: MST Radar. The radar appears to have suffered from mild interference between approximately 04:40 and 06:20 UTC. The st-mode data products should be treated with caution for the altitude ranges 4.5 - 9.0 km and above 14 km.
Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met Instruments. The single tip registered for the tipping bucket rain gauge between 11:00 and 11:10 UTC was probably the result of melting of melting frost.

Instrument: Broadband modem. The modem lost its internet connection shortly after 05:21 UTC, apparently as the result of a nearby thunderstorm. No other equipment appears to have been affected and the internet connection was restored at around 12:00 when the modem was power-cycled by DW, who happened to be on site.

Instrument: MST Radar. All data products after 19:57 UTC should be ignored. A communications error between the radar control and beam steering PCs resulted in the beam being stuck in a single pointing direction (probably number 15, SW6).

Instrument: MST Radar. All data products prior to 09:36 UTC should be ignored. A communications error between the radar control and beam steering PCs resulted in the radar being out of operation overnight. Although the radar was restarted at 08:25 UTC, the beam was stuck in a single pointing direction (the Vertical). Both the radar control and beam steering PCs were rebooted before the radar was restarted at 09:36 UTC.
Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met Instruments. The single tip registered for the tipping bucket rain gauge between 11:00 and 11:10 UTC was probably the result of melting frost.
Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met Instruments. The single tip registered for the tipping bucket rain gauge between 11:00 and 11:10 UTC was probably the result of melting frost.
Instrument: Campbell Scientific Surface Met Instruments. The single tip registered for the tipping bucket rain gauge between 09:50 and 10:00 UTC was possibly the result of melting frost.

Instrument: MST Radar. Horizontal wind data should be ignored between times of 20:30 and 21:20 UTC at altitudes of around 17.5 km. The speeds are unrealistically large compared to those at adjacent times and altitudes.

Instrument: MST Radar. Horizontal wind data should be ignored between times of 16:40 and 17:00 UTC at altitudes of around 2.5 km. The speeds are unrealistically large compared to those at adjacent times and altitudes.

Instrument: MST Radar. Horizontal wind data should be ignored between times of 04:20 and 05:00 UTC at altitudes of around 17.5 km. The speeds are unrealistically large compared to those at adjacent times and altitudes.

Instrument: MST Radar. All data products between 17:16 and 20:26 UTC should be ignored. A communications error between the radar control and beam steering PCs, which first began at 17:16 UTC, led to the beam pointing direction only changing occasionally. It eventually led to the radar control software locking up. DAH rebooted both PCs and restarted the radar at 20:26 UTC.
